data.text: Contents
Introduction and overview
It is estimated that malnutrition (undernutrition) affects over 3 million people in the UK.

In the secondary care setting disease related malnutrition results in increased complications (e.g. wound infections, chest infections, pressure ulcers), increased length of stay, increased mortality, and an increase in patients requiring readmission.
It is essential to screen patient for malnutrition or risk of malnutrition on admission to hospital to identify people who would benefit from active nutrition or hydration support.
It is the responsibility of all healthcare professionals to ensure that nutritional care is an integral part of their practice.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Set out procedures for assessing and screening for malnutrition
Identify management plans for those patients that are identified as malnourished or at risk of malnutrition.
Definitions

table_items.text: A state of nutrition in which a deficiency or excess (or imbalance) of energy, protein and/or other nutrients causes measurable adverse effects on tissue/body form (body shape, size and composition), function or clinical outcome.
A five-step screening tool used to identify adults who are malnourished or at risk of malnutrition, used at Basildon and Broomfield Hospitals
SUNS: Southend University Hospital Nutrition Screening Tool
A screening tool used at Southend Hospital to identify malnutrition and/or those requiring dietetic input.
The provision of nutrients and any additional therapeutic agents for patients orally, enterally or via the parenteral route
A product for oral administration given with the aim of improving or maintaining a patient's nutritional status.
For the purposes of this policy, enteral nutrition refers to the delivery of
nutrition via a tube into the gastrointestinal tract, given for the purpose of improving or maintaining a patient's nutritional status.
The intravenous administration of nutrients. This may be supplemental to oral or enteral nutrition, or it may be the sole source of nutrition

A policy in place to protect mealtimes from unnecessary and avoidable interruptions, predominantly arising from routine ward activities. The aim is to provide an environment conducive to eating; ensuring staff provide patients with support and assistance with meals, placing food and drink first at mealtimes.
Severe fluid and electrolyte shifts and related metabolic complications in malnourished patients undergoing refeeding.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities
Chief Executive

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, the post holder is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. They will delegate the full implementation of this document to the Chief Nursing Office and Directors of Nursing.
Medical Directors' and Consultants
To ensure that all relevant medical staff are aware of this policy and appropriately trained and updated.
Chief Nursing Officer and Directors of Nursing

Are responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non- medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Deputy Directors of Nursing
The Deputy Directors of Nursing have operational responsibility for the implementation of this policy.
Associate Directors of Nursing

The Associate Directors of Nursing are responsible for ensuring that all patients on admission to hospital or at initial out-patient attendance are screened for malnutrition, and that wards and departments are compliant with the standards in this document.
Matrons

Matrons have responsibility for monitoring and reviewing ward and department compliance with screening and assessment undertaken as part of perfect ward. Results will be reviewed at the CSU performance review meeting. They will be required to provide reports of any audits or monitoring of this document to the Nutrition and Hydration Strategy Group.
Lead Dietitian

The lead dietitian with the support of the dietitians is responsible for undertaking staff training and monitoring compliance with the standards set out in the document. The dietitians are responsible for assessing patients referred to them, and advising regarding appropriate nutritional management.
Lead Nutrition Nurse – Nutrition Support

The Lead Nutrition Nurse has responsibility for monitoring ward and department compliance against the standards set out in this policy at the Nutrition and Hydration Strategy Group with support of the nutrition nurses. In conjunction with the dietetic service they are responsible for ensuring suitable training on nutrition screening is available for nurses, doctors and other health care professionals across the Trust.
Nutrition Nurses
The Nutrition Nurse Team are responsible for undertaking staff training and monitoring compliance with the standards set out in the document.
Medical Staff

As part of the initial medical assessment, medical staff should ascertain relevant medical history that will or has impacted on the patients nutritional status. This will include a record of weight and weight loss over time. Medical staff should refer patients with clinical concern onto the dietetic service or nutrition team as appropriate.
Ward and Department Managers / Senior Sisters

All Ward and Department Managers / Senior Sisters must ensure that the standards set within this policy are adhered to. They must ensure that all appropriate staff are competent to nutritionally screen patients and any new starters should undertake training as part of their induction. Additionally, responsibility for ensuring servicing and maintenance of screening equipment lies with them.
Registered Nurses

Registered Nurses (RNs) are responsible for ensuring that a nursing nutrition assessment and nutritional screening is carried out correctly and within 24 hours of admission to hospital, it remains the responsibility of the RN and should not be delegated to a non-registered support worker. Nutrition screening does not replace a RNs clinical judgement, and RNs must refer patients on for further assessment or support where there is clinical concern. For in-patients the nutritional screen is recorded into the nursing risk assessment document, for out-patients it is usually recorded directly into the healthcare records, or pre-assessment documentation.
Speech & Language Therapists (SALT)

The speech and language therapists are responsible for ensuring patients with dysphagia have timely assessment of their disorder and an appropriate management plan to ensure adequate nutrition can be provided in an appropriate form or to highlight to the medical/nursing team when there are issues regarding dysphagia which may compromise adequate nutritional management to enable referral to the dietetic service. The SALT team are also responsible for training of qualified nurses to screen patients for dysphagia and to have competency to manage this dysphagia appropriately.
Pharmacy

The pharmacy team are responsible for supplying nutritional supplements and parenteral nutrition in accordance with agreed clinical area stock lists and patient- specific prescriptions to the relevant clinical areas. These will be in accordance with the agreed nutritional supplements and parenteral nutrition formulary. They will advise regarding any interactions between nutrients and drugs. The pharmacy team advise and supply medication in a suitable form for optimal uptake and where administration is via an enteral feeding tube to minimise tube blockage or damage to the tube. This is in accordance with Trust Medication Policies.
Catering

The catering team will develop menus in conjunction with the Nutrition and Dietetic Department to ensure that all patients' nutrition and hydration needs can be met. They will ensure that meal provision takes into account patients' clinical, cultural and religious beliefs.
Assessment and screening

There is no 'gold standard' indicator that exclusively relates to the assessment of a patient's nutritional status. A combination of tests need to be applied, these include taking a dietary history, anthropometric measurements, a physical examination and biochemical analysis.

On admission to hospital adult patients will have their nutritional status screened within 24 hours of admission using 'MUST' (Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool, Elia 2003) (Appendix 1) or ‘SUNS' at Southend Hospital (Appendix 2).

All patients attending an initial out-patient appointment should be nutritionally screened as part of the initial assessment process, unless the department is considered to have a low risk population group, in which case they may ‘opt out' (NICE 2006). To opt out the clinician responsible for that particular out-patient department, must put the request for consideration into writing addressed to the Chair of the MSE Nutrition Steering Group. The request will be considered at the next meeting, and a response considered on clinical grounds by nutrition experts. A list of all ‘opt out' departments will be held by the MSE Nutrition Steering Group.

Each ward or department will have weighing scales and a device for measuring height or use surrogate measurements to estimate height. It is the Ward Sister / Unit Manager's responsibility to ensure that these devices are available, serviced and maintained according to the manufacturer instructions.
All patients should be weighed on admission and weekly thereafter, sooner if there is a change in the patient's condition. Bed weighing scales should be utilised where available and appropriate.

All patients should have their height recorded on admission. An actual height will be most accurate, but if this cannot be obtained a surrogate measure such as ulna length, or reported height may be used, but should be clearly be documented as such.
The ‘MUST' or ‘SUNS' score will be documented into the patients' healthcare records.
Where patients have swallowing problems, dysphagia trained nurses may undertake a dysphagia screen, following Trust protocol and documentation. Patients

with complex disorders/tracheostomy tubes/altered anatomy will be assessed by a Speech and Language Therapist, who will also manage all patients dysphagia lasting more than 24 hrs. Refer to MSE Dysphagia policy.

Patients with a learning disability may have additional needs, and therefore will need to be assessed by someone with specialist knowledge of nutrition care in this condition, in the presence of their relative or carer who knows them and who can offer appropriate advice. Additional support from the Learning Disability Nurse Advisor for the Trust can be obtained if necessary.
Any mental health issues impacting a patient's ability to eat and drink will require specialist input from professionals working in this field.

Patients with dementia may have additional needs, and therefore will need to be assessed by someone with specialist knowledge of nutritional care in this condition and in the presence of their relative or carer who can offer appropriate advice. Additional support should be sought from the dementia specialists.
Referral

Following screening the appropriate care pathway should be followed according to the identified risk of malnutrition. Patients who are malnourished or at high risk of becoming malnourished must be referred to the appropriate trained personnel.
Adult patients should be referred to the Dietitian if:
Nutritional screening highlights a patient at high risk of malnutrition.
The patient is admitted with special / therapeutic dietary requirements that cannot be met by the hospital menu choices
They are diagnosed as needing special / therapeutic dietary advice whilst in hospital
Nutritional requirements cannot be met orally and other routes of feeding need to be considered e.g. NG, PEG or parenteral nutrition
Referral to the Dietitian shall be made as per local site arrangements.
Where there is a nutrition team in place the following patients can be referred ;
Patients requiring enteral access devices e.g. naso-gastric tubes or gastrostomy tube
Those where there is difficulty in confirming naso-gastric tube position
Those who usually receive enteral or parenteral nutrition at home
Patients for assessment for Parenteral nutrition
There are complex metabolic, fluid or electrolyte disturbances requiring correction e.g. high output stoma
Referral to the Nutrition Support Team can be made as per local site arrangements.

Where patients are observed to have swallowing problems or assessed as at risk, a referral to the Speech and Language Therapist should be made. On wards where Dysphagia Trained Nurses (DTN) are available these patients should be screened prior to referral to the Speech and Language Therapist. Referrals should be made to SLT as per local site arrangements.
Treatment
Patients identified at risk of malnutrition should have an individual care plan instigated as per screening recommendation. This may include the following interventions:
Food record chart
Red Tray / red jug
Ensuring the patient gets assistance to eat and drink
Identifying patient preferences
Helping the patient to choose appropriate meals from the menu, including ensuring appropriate consistency of food/fluid is provided to those patients with dysphagia.
High energy/protein menu options
Care Plan
Nutritional supplement drinks
Referral to the dietitian
Referral to the SLT
Referral to the Nutrition Support Team

Protected mealtimes should be in place on all wards, interruptions to patients e.g. ward round, doctors visit, cleaning, and therapy, should only occur in exceptional circumstances, to promote a conducive environment for eating. Please refer to the MSE Protected Mealtimes policy for further details.

The Dietitian will make a detailed nutritional assessment, a summary of which will be written into the health care records. This will include an assessment of weight, height, body mass index, estimated requirements and aims / expected outcomes of nutritional support.
The Dietitian will identify which particular nutrients may be deficient in the patients' diet and advise regarding an appropriate diet or recommend feeding via the enteral or parenteral route.

In many instances therapeutic diets can be ordered from the main menu. If the menu does not meet the needs of the patient, ward staff should liaise with dietetics and catering to ensure appropriate meals are provided.
The SLT will assess the patient as per the dysphagia policy and will recommend the safest consistency food and fluid for the patient. This will be documented in the patient's records.

The nutrition nurses in conjunction with the dietitians, will assess patients for the appropriateness of enteral feeding, and consider the most suitable route of feeding. The nutrition nurses will support placement of enteral feeding devices where indicated.
The nutrition support team will assess patients requiring parenteral nutrition, and those with complex nutritional needs.
The healthcare professionals involved in the nutritional assessment and management of patients, will regularly review and advise regarding the most suitable interventions.

If it is felt an individual lacks capacity to make safe and appropriate food and fluid choices for themselves, a MCA should be completed (See MSE policy) and a decision should be made involving the MDT and family regarding feeding.
Training requirements
Training on nutritional screening tools via i-learn or via local in person training.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Adherence in the completion of the screening tools

data.text: The monitoring and audit relating to nutrition screening will be reported to the Nutrition and Hydration Steering Group.
Results of audit and any action plans will be monitored through the MSE Nutrition Steering Group
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Nutrition and Hydration Steering Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Nutrition and Hydration Steering Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary Equality Analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 3)
References

BAPEN (2018) Introduction to malnutrition: What is the size of the problem in the UK On-line at https://www.bapen.org.uk/malnutrition-undernutrition/introduction-to- malnutrition?start=4  [Accessed 10/12/2021]

Elia M (ed) (2003). The 'MUST' report. Nutritional screening for adults: a multidisciplinary responsibility. Development and use of the 'Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool' ('MUST') for adults. On-line at https://www.bapen.org.uk/pdfs/must/must-report.pdf [Accessed 10/12/2021]

Nursing and Midwifery Council (2018) The Code – Professional standards of practice and behaviour for nurses, midwives and nursing associates. On-line at https://www.nmc.org.uk/globalassets/sitedocuments/nmc-publications/nmc-code.pdf [Accessed 10/12/2021]
Appendix 1: Malnutrition Universal Screening tool (MUST)

data.text: Date:…………………. To be completed on admission to  Nurse signature……..
ward for every patient**
(Not appropriate for Critical Care Patients)  ………………………
** Pregnant women on the Maternity Unit do not need to be screened unless certain triggers present (see overleaf)
Weight: …………kg
PLEASE TICK  ALL RELEVANT CRITERIA

table_items.text: Feeding tube in situ (e.g. NG, NJ or PEG)** Major GI / Maxfac / ENT surgery** Intestinal Failure Neurological condition presenting with dysphagia (excluding dementia) Renal failure requiring dialysis or dietary restriction** Liver failure or decompensated liver disease** Newly diagnosed diabetic** Newly diagnosed coeliac** Has eaten LESS THAN ¼ of most meals for the past 5 days Has had UNINTENTIONAL weight loss of more than 5 kg over the last 3 months (or since initial assessment) Nutritional intake remains low – 7 days after initial amber referral If parenteral nutrition is required**, please contact the nutrition team: Nutrition Support Dietitian: bleep 3557 Nutrition Nurse: bleep 1144 Surgical Pharmacist: bleep 1177 **Please tick to indicate that this referral has been discussed with the ward doctor, approved and written in the medical notes □

Has had UNINTENTIONAL weight loss of 1-4 kg over past 3 months (or since initial assessment). Has eaten less than half of most meals for over 3 days. (do not tick if patient NBM) Has an infected mouth / sore mouth / very dry mouth Has an Infection / pyrexia Requires feeding or regular encouragement to eat meals Has grade 3 or 4 wounds / pressure sores (refer to wound/pressure sore policy on ward) Has had surgery in the last 7 days Has been NBM for 2 days or more in the past 7 days Patient has known learning disability

data.text: ACTION

table_items.text: If a patient has been ticked as red for ANY of the above, refer immediately to a dietitian

If a patient has met at least 3 amber criteria, commence the following immediately and reassess after 7 days: Start on a food chart Encourage high energy meals from menu Offer snacks from ward provisions Offer regular cups of full fat milk (if not allergic or intolerant to dairy) Commence on ‘Ensure Compact' or ‘Ensure Plus Juce' if appropriate – 2 per day If a patient has met 2 or less amber criteria, reassess weekly and consider taking the above actions to improve nutritional status:
If a patient has been circled as green reassess weekly

data.text: **Pregnant women do not need to be screened unless any of the following trigger factors are
present: -
Hyperemesis
Reduced appetite/has eaten less than 50% of usual intake for more than 5 days
Unintentional weight loss whilst pregnant
